Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: @allbits#8882   Demurrage  and interest are not equivalent .

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: Interest rate is charge on principal. You are not paying 50% of your principal.  Additionally locking coins up in a peg necessarily prevents them from being able to the required action to receive the reward

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content:
@eBit If I may add (I haven't read the whole conversation) to answer your question. When you deposit the funds in pegscc account, let say your example of 3000KMD, you are able to get up to 80% of value of your deposit at that moment. So if price of gold is 1500 KMD (we will avoid USD as JL mentioned we can have direct price but lets say 1 KMD 1$ so if 1500$ is the price of gold then lets say at that moment price of gold in KMD is 1500), you can get maximum 1.6 KGOLD. Again let take your example that you took 1 KGOLD, now the price went up, if you want to get back to KMD, you will get back your deposit so 3000KMD there is no 900KMD.
PegsCC must be looked as a mechanisom of deposit vs. borrow. You give the bank your house and take 200k$ loan, when you return the loan you get back the house.

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: So you are not making any money with just holding KGOLD or whatever pegged coin, but you can lose money üòõ

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: On the other hand if you acquire more KGOLD, then you can exchange it for more tokens.

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: The problem gose when price goes down. If it goes up you can always take more KGOLD if you want (not necessary). But if it goes down, then you would need to return, but instead of making a system which would burn coins and take it from users, this system works that someone can repay your debt and take your deposit. Then you are left with your KGOLD and you can exchange it for KMD, but you lost some of it as now the price is lower and you cannot get as much as you deposited.

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: It is very confusing and complex at beginning, but when you grasp the fundamentals then everything is logical.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes. the issuance/liquidation process is not anything most people have to do. once it is put into circulation, it should trade at close to the pegged value

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: Someone needs to deposit in order for coins to be issued. But you can always just buy coins regularly. I think most of the people which will make deposits, they will do the liquidation part for profit. Others will regularly use the coins.

Author: allbits#5898
Content: @polycryptoblog demurrage?? Not sure you're using the right terminology, so your point is lost if you have one. Opportunity cost is cost. I think it's silly to hope nobody would take the opportunity cost Into account when locking KMD

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: Demurrage = fee for storage .   Interest = payment from borrower on and above the amount borrowed .          How do you figure you are paying a 50% interest rate on a 10:1 peg?

Author: allbits#5898
Content:
Opportunity cost. It's very simple - I feel like you're being willfully blind to a simple point. I have 100 kmd. If I lock it for a year, I forgo about 5% = 5  kmd

If I borrow the equivalent of 10 kmd for that period (the ten percent example) I'm incurring a cost of 5 to borrow 10. There it is. Nothing to do with inaccurately applied terms like demurrage.  Just a simple cost benefit analysis like most normal people would do here.

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: Ok I get what you mean now,  by your description , interest is also an inaccurate term as well.   Opportunity cost != interest

Author: allbits#5898
Content: The effect is the same. Presenting this as interest free loan is misleading

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: If the deposit was not KMD ,  which is possible by cc-peg , then is it misleading?

Author: allbits#5898
Content: If the deposited coin is a coin that does not have rewards built in, it is quite different.

Author: allbits#5898
Content: There is slippage or inefficiency when setting up this system with KMD because the rewards "disappear"

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the cc-pegs is implemented as interest free loan, it is coin agnostic. the fact that if using KMD has an opportunity cost is independent of the cc-pegs

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: That‚Äôs what I was trying to get at thanks @jl777c

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but for KMD, which is the coin that makes sense to use, it does have a cost of the lost rewards, which is very real for people that actively collect rewards (about half). the upside is that these rewards can go toward compensating the multisig signers

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: that makes it a sustainable setup and for shorter term usage, the 0.4% per month is really smaller than most spreads, so shouldnt be much of a factor

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i think it is fair to describe cc-pegs as being similar to an interest free loan, we just need to explain that if KMD is used, the rewards are going to the multisig signers

Author: allbits#5898
Content: pegs on mBTC might be more attractive for long term - interest free loan on my btc by first converting it to the mBTC chain that you are setting up.
